Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: At the end of the shift, it's time for the routine sweep-up of your designated work area.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as the foreman barked out the end-of-shift orders. My boots crunched over scattered debris—nails, splinters, dust—reminding me of the safety protocols drilled into us every morning. “No one leaves until the site’s clean,” he’d said, and I knew the risks: a single stray nail could mean a trip to the ER for someone tomorrow. But as I grabbed the broom, my phone buzzed. The reminder flashed: court session in thirty minutes. As an advocate, I couldn’t afford to be late, not today. The case was at a tipping point, and my client’s future might hinge on my presence. My stomach twisted. If I left now, I’d be abandoning my crew and risking someone’s safety. If I stayed, I’d be letting down my client and possibly jeopardizing the case. The weight of both uniforms pressed on me, each demanding my loyalty, each unforgiving of compromise. I stood frozen, broom in hand, heart pounding, torn between two worlds that refused to overlap.
